title: "Powerful IDE for Professional Development, but Heavy on Resources."
body:
5/5What do you like best about Visual Studio?Visual Studio offers a complete and professional development environment with powerful tools like IntelliSense, live debugging, built-in Git integration, and seamless Azure deployment. I especially appreciate how it streamlines complex workflows — from writing code to testing and deploying — all in one place. Its support for multiple languages and frameworks makes it incredibly versatile for full-stack development. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What do you dislike about Visual Studio?Visual Studio can be resource-intensive, especially on older machines — it tends to slow down or lag with larger projects. The initial setup and installation process is also quite lengthy. Additionally, some features are locked behind higher-tier licenses, which can be limiting for smaller teams or individual developers. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What problems is Visual Studio solving and how is that benefiting you?Visual Studio streamlines the entire development lifecycle — from writing code to debugging and deploying. It helps me manage large codebases efficiently with powerful IntelliSense, code navigation, and integrated testing tools. Having everything in one place improves productivity and reduces the need to switch between tools, which saves time and reduces errors. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
Show More
author: Eashan M.

title: ""Mastering My Projects with Visual Studio — 2 Years of Django to Debugging""
body:
4.5/5What do you like best about Visual Studio?Visual Studio makes coding much easier with its smart IntelliSense feature. It automatically suggests code, helps find errors quickly, and supports many programming languages.
 I've been using Visual Studio from last 2 years, and its extensions make it the best for coding. You can easily add tools that suit your development needs. The reusability of code becomes easier, and it shows errors in real-time, which saves a lot of debugging time. The best part is that you can do everything — from frontend coding to backend development and even database management — all in one place. It's a complete full-stack solution for developers. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What do you dislike about Visual Studio?The startup time is often slow, especially when multiple extensions are installed. The unpaid version of Blackbox isn’t very effective and lacks many useful features. Also, sometimes two different extensions conflict with each other, causing functionality issues.
Also, multiple windows and tabs often make it complex to use, especially when creating or managing new files. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What problems is Visual Studio solving and how is that benefiting you?Visual Studio solves the problem of managing a full-stack development workflow by bringing everything into one clean, powerful interface. From writing frontend code to building complex Django-based backend systems, I can handle everything in one place.Its support for GitHub makes version control incredibly easy — I can clone repos, manage branches, commit, push, pull, and even resolve merge conflicts directly within the IDE. This integration saves me from constantly switching to terminal or external Git tools.
The best part is: I don't need to juggle multiple apps. From writing code to debugging to GitHub collaboration — everything is smooth, fast, and productive. It's a huge time-saver and makes development much more professional and enjoyable. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
Show More

author: Nikhil J.

title: "Great all-in-one IDE with tools that make coding easier"
body:
4.5/5What do you like best about Visual Studio?- The debugger is very useful, I can step through code and watch variables change instead of printing stuff everywhere just to see what’s going on.
- IntelliSense catches my typos and reminds me of method parameters when my brain blanks out, which happens more often than I’d like to admit.
- Everything I need is built-in. I can handle Git, manage packages, and run tests without juggling multiple tools.
- Renaming across the whole solution is easy, the refactor tool actually finds every usage and updates it.
- The extension marketplace has come through for me more than once. There’s usually a plugin for whatever odd tech I’m dealing with that day. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What do you dislike about Visual Studio?- Large projects slow it down a lot and memory usage spikes, so the whole IDE starts lagging.
- It takes a huge amount of disk space just to install, way more than any other tool I use. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What problems is Visual Studio solving and how is that benefiting you?It brings everything needed into one place, so there's no jumping between different apps for coding, debugging, testing, or Git. it makes it easier to stay focused. The debugger helps find bugs faster without flooding code with print statements. Refactoring tools save time when making big changes. And with the right extensions, it fits into almost any project or workflow. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

author: Toba Toba P.

title: "Friend of developer is Visual Studio"
body:
4.5/5What do you like best about Visual Studio?Visual Studio is one of the most popular and powerful integrated development environments (IDEs), and there's a lot to like about it. First and foremost, Visual Studio’s IntelliSense is incredibly helpful. Robust Debugging Tools. Seamless Integration with Azure and Git.Multi-Platform Development
With .NET MAUI, Blazor, and support for Xamarin, Visual Studio enables cross-platform development from a single codebase. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What do you dislike about Visual Studio?While Visual Studio is a powerful and feature-rich IDE, it’s not without its drawbacks. Here are some common criticisms and pain points:
1.It consumes a lot of memory and CPU, especially with large solutions.
2.Installing Visual Studio, particularly with multiple workloads (e.g., .NET, C++, MAUI), can take a long time.
3. Updates are frequent and often large, and sometimes they disrupt workflow with unexpected changes or regressions.
4. Platform-Specific Limitations, for mac it's stopped supporting. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What problems is Visual Studio solving and how is that benefiting you?Visual Studio solves a wide range of development challenges by offering an integrated, powerful, and flexible environment for building software. Here's how that benefits developers like :
1.All-in-One Development Environment
Problem Solved: Switching between tools for coding, debugging, testing, and deployment wastes time and increases errors.
Benefit: Visual Studio unifies everything in one IDE—code editor, designer, debugger, profiler, Git integration, unit test runner, and deployment tools—so you stay productive and focused.

2.Streamlining .NET and Cross-Platform App Development
Problem Solved: Managing multiple toolchains for web, desktop, mobile, and cloud development is complex.
Benefit: With support for .NET MAUI, Blazor, ASP.NET, WPF, WinForms, Azure, and more, Visual Studio enables you to build full-stack, cross-platform applications from a single codebase—ideal for teams targeting multiple platforms.

3. Debugging Complex Applications.
4. Supporting Testing and Quality Assurance. Visual Studio includes a Test Explorer, code coverage tools, and profilers, all helping you ensure code quality without needing external tools.
5. Built-in Git/GitHub/Azure DevOps integration, Live Share, and Azure deployment tools support efficient collaboration and smooth DevOps pipelines. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

author: Divyarani D.

title: "Review on Visual Studio"
body:
3.5/5What do you like best about Visual Studio?What I like best about Visual Studio is its powerful IntelliSense, which makes coding faster and easier with real-time code suggestions. The integrated debugger is incredibly helpful for identifying and fixing issues efficiently. I appreciate the seamless Git integration for version control. Visual Studio's support for multiple programming languages and project types makes it versatile. The user interface is clean, customizable, and beginner-friendly. Its vast extension marketplace allows developers to tailor the IDE to their workflow. Built-in tools like Live Share enable real-time collaboration. Performance profiling and diagnostics tools are also very useful. It supports Azure integration out of the box. Overall, it’s a robust and comprehensive development environment. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What do you dislike about Visual Studio?What I dislike about Visual Studio is that it can be quite heavy and slow to load, especially on older machines. The installation process is lengthy and requires significant disk space. Sometimes, it feels bloated with too many features that aren't always needed. It can occasionally crash or freeze during large projects. Updates are frequent and can disrupt workflow. The licensing for the full version is expensive for individual developers. Its performance with large solutions can degrade over time. Customizing settings can be overwhelming for beginners. Some extensions cause instability. Despite its power, it’s not always the most lightweight or responsive IDE. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What problems is Visual Studio solving and how is that benefiting you?isual Studio solves the problem of managing complex software development by providing an all-in-one integrated development environment. It combines code editing, debugging, testing, and version control in a single platform, which improves productivity and reduces context switching. With features like IntelliSense and code navigation, it helps me write accurate, efficient code faster. The built-in debugger simplifies finding and fixing bugs, saving valuable time. Integration with Git and Azure streamlines deployment and collaboration. Its support for multiple languages and project types allows me to work on diverse applications without changing tools. Overall, it helps me build high-quality software more efficiently. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.

It auto-suggests extensions to be installed, making the platform flexible for any type of file ranging from Python code files and python notebooks to even PDFs. author: Mukesh K.

title: "Best IDE in the market for most tech stack, although getting behind on AI driven development."
body:
4.5/5What do you like best about Visual Studio?I'm a software dev and VSCode has become an indispensable part of my workflow. What I like most? everything. Its ability to handle large projects with countless files while maintaining exceptional performance. The editor remains responsive, even when working on monolith projects with complex dependencies or giant codebases. The mini-map is nice, so if you have been a fan of Sublime then you won't be lost. Also, with the seamless integration of keyboard shortcuts, you can become incredibly efficient by never lifting fingers from your keyboard.

But truly, what I like most about VSCode is that there seems to be an extension for everything, you can customize your environment tailored to your every need. Extensions like GitLens make version control straightforward by providing visual indicators for changes, commit history, and author insights. AI tools, such as Copilot, take productivity to another level by suggesting code snippets and solutions as you type, or AmazonQ help integrate cloud-specific solutions, and code generators. But also, there is a small extension for any productivity improvement you can imagine, few things I have installed: a color picker while coding CSS, a live preview for frontend projects, batch file renames, char count, and also several code snippets and boilerplate generators for HTML, Ruby, Python, etc. I have seach and found even a SUM extension for selected numbers on a file... 

Finally, one thing I really like about VSCode is how it works with modern frameworks and technologies. It provides excellent support for building apps with Flutter, React, and Ionic, among many others. From setting up a project to debugging and testing, I can control everything directly from the editor. Whether it’s running a Flutter emulator, managing a React build process, or deploying an Ionic app, VSCode handles it all seamlessly.
Its integrated a terminal, debugger, and task runner.

Summary, it is a powerhouse for developers, and you will enjoy working on your products. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What do you dislike about Visual Studio?I've been testing latetly the AI Copilot extensions and all Copilot recent releases for VSCode. I would had loved if it was fully integrated with the IDE, currently only supports the file you have openned, Copilot will give you great code completitions suggestions, but it lacks context on your entire openned project. At this point developers are moving towars an AI asisted development environment, so IDEs such as Cursor and Windsurf that are actually based on VSCode are having such a great adoption and a huge advantage than VSCode Today. Although I think VSCode is moving to the right direction, I think it is moving slowly considering Copilot is also from Microsoft.

I love how you can extend VSCode and pretty much customize it for your preferable development environment, it is a manual that by now it should have been part of a sign up onBoarding wizard, the IDE asking you what tech stack you use and/or pick it automatically from your openned project and automatically install the extensions you need. It lacks that level of sofisticated recommendation. And, if you check the actual Recommended Extensions most cases are not even close to what we need on a project. Definitely I do not like how the actual Extensions recommendations works.

One other thing I don't like much is how complex configurations are required for native mobile developmebt, I would still recommend Xcode and Android Studio for native Swift and Kotlin. Example, for native development you don't have yet a way to build the apps and run infrom on the simulator directly from VSCode. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What problems is Visual Studio solving and how is that benefiting you?It simplifies development, version control and debugging. With built-in tools and extensions like GitLens and Copilot it boosts productivity and allows writing code and deploying apps—in one single integrated environment.

author: gopal s.

title: "Usage for Visual Studio"
body:
3.5/5What do you like best about Visual Studio?What I like best about Visual Studio is its powerful and comprehensive set of tools for software development. The integrated development environment (IDE) is highly intuitive, with features like IntelliSense for smart code completion, robust debugging tools, and seamless integration with version control systems like Git. It supports multiple programming languages and frameworks, making it versatile for various projects. Additionally, the ability to extend its functionality with plugins and extensions enhances productivity significantly. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What do you dislike about Visual Studio?One thing I dislike about Visual Studio is that it can be resource-intensive, especially when working on large projects, which sometimes leads to slower performance or longer load times. Additionally, while the interface is feature-rich, it can feel overwhelming for beginners due to its complexity and the number of options available. The frequent updates, though beneficial, can occasionally cause compatibility issues with extensions or disrupt workflows. Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.What problems is Visual Studio solving and how is that benefiting you?Visual Studio can help you be more productive by: 
Using keyboard shortcuts 
Using extensions like Visual Assist, which can help with refactoring, navigation, code generation, and more 
Using advanced navigation features to quickly go to any file, method, reference, or code symbol Review collected by and hosted on G2.com.
